abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
<jats:title>Background</jats:title>
<jats:p>Mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly (MFDM) is characteristic of multiple skeletal anomalies comprising craniofacial anomalies/dysplasia, microcephaly, dysplastic ears, choanal atresia, and short stature. Heterozygous loss of function variants of <jats:italic>EFTUD2</jats:italic> was previously reported in MFDM; however, the mechanism underlying <jats:italic>EFTUD2</jats:italic>-associated skeletal dysplasia remains unclear.</jats:p>
</jats:sec><jats:sec>
<jats:title>Results</jats:title>
<jats:p>We identified a novel frameshift variant of <jats:italic>EFTUD2</jats:italic> (c.1030_1031delTG, p.Trp344fs*2) in an MFDM Chinese patient with craniofacial dysmorphism including ear canal structures and microcephaly, mild intellectual disability, and developmental delay. We generated a zebrafish model of <jats:italic>eftud2</jats:italic> deficiency, and a consistent phenotype consisting of mandibular bone dysplasia and otolith loss was observed. We also showed that <jats:italic>EFTUD2</jats:italic> deficiency significantly inhibited proliferation, differentiation, and maturation in human calvarial osteoblast (HCO) and human articular chondrocyte (HC-a) cells. RNA-Seq analysis uncovered activated <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> signaling with increased phosphorylation of the TP53 protein and upregulation of five <jats:italic>TP53</jats:italic> downstream target genes (<jats:italic>FAS</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>STEAP3</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>CASP3</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>P21</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>SESN1</jats:italic>) both in HCO and in <jats:italic>eftud2</jats:italic>−/− zebrafish. Additionally, inhibition of <jats:italic>p53</jats:italic> by morpholino significantly reduced the mortality of <jats:italic>eftud2</jats:italic>−/− larvae.</jats:p>
</jats:sec><jats:sec>
<jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
<jats:p>Our results confirm a novel de novo variant of the <jats:italic>EFTUD2</jats:italic> gene and suggest that <jats:italic>EFTUD2</jats:italic> may participate in the maturation and differentiation of osteoblasts and chondrocytes, possibly via activation of the TP53 signaling pathway. Thus, mutations in this gene may lead to skeletal anomalies in vertebrates.</jats:p>
</jats:sec>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This study was with by the approval of the faculty Ethics Committee of Children's Hospital of Fudan University, and written informed consent was obtained from the patient or his parents.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The patient’s consent was collected from his legal representatives for the publication of this study.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

title: EFTUD2 gene deficiency disrupts osteoblast maturation and inhibits chondrocyte differentiation via activation of the p53 signaling pathway
